abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the outcome of the project was
            satisfactory. However, targets for enrollment increase as
            well as those for internal efficiency at every level, were
            not achieved. A number of key lessons were drawn from this
            project, mostly as it relates to decentralization, with
            applicability to other sectors as well. The following are
            the main lessons learned: 1) participation at all levels was
            proven effective in project implementation, thus the
            development of social capital, team formation, and regional
            continuity are additional benefits derived from this
            approach; 2) redeployment of staff at local level, i.e.,
            within school districts, was a well proven policy option,
            with needs for further diversification of specific
            initiatives, such as misdistribution and underemployment of
            staff; 3) experience suggests that management capacity has
            to develop first at regional levels before being delegated
            to district levels, hence a gradual planned and phased
            approach to responsibility devolution and capacity building
            is needed; 4) a participating local community can
            effectively identify its own priorities and deliver
            sustainable quality primary education, if given initiative
            and modest resources; 5) financial and budgetary constraints
            forced sector institutions towards efficiency and better
            utilization of resources.

18150257.majtheme: Human development,Social protection and risk management,Public sector governance

abstracts.cdata!:
This project is intended to start a
            major reform of the education sector, through policy
            measures and quality improvements. The project has three
            main components: 1) strengthening administration and
            planning in MINESEB, 2) quality improvement of basic and
            lower secondary education and 3) strengthening higher level
            education. Both economic and educational benefits are
            expected. The institutional measures will improve long term
            resource allocation, allowing strengthening  of quality and
            increased enrollment to respond to demographic pressures,
            within the education budget likely to be available. The
            project will increase student achievements at all levels and
            reduce costs by allowing students to complete education
            cycles more quickly.
